DistractorFacts.fact: Mammon in Hebrew (ממון) means "money". The word was adopted to modern Hebrew to mean wealth. DistractorFacts.fact: For the most part, beryllium oxide is produced as a white amorphous powder, sintered into larger shapes. Impurities, like carbon, can give a variety of colours to the otherwise colourless host crystals. Sintered beryllium oxide is a very stable ceramic.

Question: Is approach surveillance radar more reliable than non-traditional PAR?
Answer: Yes

DistractorFacts.fact: A helipad is a landing area or platform for helicopters and powered lift aircraft. While helicopters and powered lift aircraft are able to operate on a variety of relatively flat surfaces, a fabricated helipad provides a clearly marked hard surface away from obstacles where such aircraft can land safely.
DistractorFacts.title: Helipad - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: An aircraft approach category is a grouping which differentiates aircraft based on the speed at which the aircraft approaches a runway for a landing. Specifically the V Ref ,of a given aircraft, at the maximum certificated landing weight (if V Ref is not specified, the approach speed is given as the V S0 multiplied by 1.3) .
DistractorFacts.title: Aircraft approach category - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: An approach slope is the path that an airplane follows on its final approach to land on a runway. It takes its name from the fact that this path is ideally a gentle downward slope. A commonly used approach slope is 3° from the horizontal.
DistractorFacts.title: Final approach (aeronautics) - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Approach lighting systems are designed to allow the pilot to quickly and positively identify visibility distances in Instrument meteorological conditions. For example, if the aircraft is at the middle marker, and the middle marker is located 3600 feet from the threshold, the Decision Bar is 2600 feet ahead.
DistractorFacts.title: Approach lighting system - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Approach/departure control facilities were created after adoption of radar in the 1950s to monitor and control the busy airspace around larger airports. The first air route traffic control center, which directs the movement of aircraft between departure and destination was opened in Newark in 1935, followed in 1936 by Chicago and Cleveland.
DistractorFacts.title: Air traffic control - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: From then on, Precision approach radars are most frequently used at military air traffic control facilities. Many of these facilities use the AN/FPN-63, AN/MPN, or AN/TPN-22. These radars can provide precision guidance to a distance of 10 to 20 miles.
DistractorFacts.title: Precision approach radar - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Ground penetrating radar survey is one method used in archaeological geophysics. GPR can be used to detect and map subsurface archaeological artifacts, features, and patterning. GPR depth slices showing a crypt in a historic cemetery. These planview maps show subsurface structures at different depths.
DistractorFacts.title: Ground-penetrating radar - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Ground station equipment may be monitored and controlled remotely, often via serial and/or IP interfaces. There are typically backup stations from which radio contact can be maintained if there is a problem at the primary ground station which renders it unable to operate, such as a natural disaster.
DistractorFacts.title: Ground segment - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The development of radar in the mid-1930s proved a great advance in air-to-ground communication. Radar could be used to track planes in the air and determine distance, direction, speed and even type of aircraft. This allowed for better air traffic control as well as navigation aides for pilots.
DistractorFacts.title: Air-to-ground communication - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The overall concept is known as ground-controlled approach (GCA), and this name was also used to refer to the radar systems in the early days of its development. PAR radars use a unique type of radar display with two separate "traces", separated vertically.
DistractorFacts.title: Precision approach radar - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. In aviation, approach surveillance radar ( ASR or SRA) is a type of radar instrument approach provided with active assistance from air traffic control. The only airborne radio equipment required for radar approaches is a functioning radio transmitter and receiver.
DistractorFacts.title: Surveillance radar approach - Wikipedia

Question: Is the Amyema miquelii species of flowering plant eaten by the Ngunnawal people?

SupportingFacts.fact: Larvae of the butterfly genus Delias often use various Amyema species as larval food plants. In doing so, the adults acquire a taste that is unpalatable to predators. DistractorFacts.title: Amyema melaleucae - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Amyema gibberula is an aerial hemiparasitic plant of the family Loranthaceae native to Australia and found in Western Australia, the Northern Territory, and South Australia. DistractorFacts.title: Amyema gibberula - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The mistletoebird is known to consume the fruit of Amyema quandang as well as other mistletoe species from which its name is derived. Larvae of the butterfly genus Delias often use various Amyema species as larval food plants.

DistractorFacts.fact: Campobasso ( UK: / ˌkæmpoʊˈbæsoʊ /, Italian: [ˌkampoˈbasso] ( listen); Campobassan: Cambuàsce [ˌkambuˈwaʃʃə]) is a city and comune in southern Italy, the capital of the region of Molise and of the province of Campobasso. It is located in the high basin of the Biferno river, surrounded by Sannio and Matese mountains.
DistractorFacts.title: Campobasso - Wikipedia

Question: What Japanese spirits, phenomena or "holy powers" that are venerated in the religion of Shinto that the amatsukami belong to?
Answer: Kami.

SupportingFacts.fact: Kami ( Japanese: 神, [kaꜜmi]) (often taken to mean " gods ", though the concept is more involved than that) are the spirits, phenomena or "holy powers" that are venerated in the religion of Shinto.
SupportingFacts.title: Kami - Wikipedia

SupportingFacts.fact: Ame became the home of the amatsukami or gods of heaven, while tsuchi became the home of kunitsukami or gods of the land. The amatsukami are said to have descended from heaven to pacify and perfect this world.
SupportingFacts.title: Takamagahara - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Ame became the home of the amatsukami or gods of heaven, while tsuchi became the home of kunitsukami or gods of the land. The amatsukami are said to have descended from heaven to pacify and perfect this world. In the beginning of the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), Takamagahara is mentioned as the birthplace of the gods.
DistractorFacts.title: Takamagahara - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In Japanese mythology, Takamagahara (高天原, "Plain of High Heaven " or "High Plain of Heaven", also read as Takaamanohara, Takamanohara, Takaamagahara, or Takaamahara ), is the abode of the heavenly gods ( amatsu kami ).
DistractorFacts.title: Takamagahara - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In Japanese religion, Yahata (八幡神, ancient Shinto pronunciation) formerly in Shinto and later commonly known as Hachiman (八幡神, Japanese Buddhist pronunciation) is the syncretic divinity of archery and war, incorporating elements from both Shinto and Buddhism.
DistractorFacts.title: Hachiman - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Marvel Comics includes many characters based on deities from several mythological pantheons. The most significant one is Thor, a character based on the deity of the same name from Norse mythology. Other deities from Norse myths were adapted for Thor's supporting cast, along with Heracles and other deities from Greek mythology.
DistractorFacts.title: List of deities in Marvel Comics - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Yamata no Orochi (ヤマタノオロチ, also 八岐大蛇 , 八俣遠呂智 or 八俣遠呂知), or simply Orochi (大蛇), is a legendary eight-headed and eight-tailed Japanese dragon / serpent. Yamata no Orochi legends are originally recorded in two ancient texts about Japanese mythology and history.
DistractorFacts.title: Yamata no Orochi - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Under Chinese Buddhist influence, the god was identified with Myōken either as the pole star or Venus, before being combined with the god of all stars, Ama-no-mi-naka-nushi (天之御中主神, "Divine Lord of the middle heavens"). In some versions he was born from Kagutsuchi 's blood.
DistractorFacts.title: Amatsumikaboshi - Wikipedia

Question: What administrative regions of Ancient Rome were generally governed by politicians of senatorial rank?
Answer: The province.

SupportingFacts.fact: David Whelan (born 24 November 1936) is an English former footballer. During his football career, he played for Blackburn Rovers and Crewe Alexandra.
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: The word province in Modern English has its origins in the Latin term used by the Romans. Provinces were generally governed by politicians of senatorial rank, usually former consuls or former praetors.
SupportingFacts.title: Roman province - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: A dictator is a political leader who possesses absolute power. A dictatorship is a state ruled by one dictator or by a small clique. The word originated as the title of a magistrate in the Roman Republic appointed by the Senate to rule the republic in times of emergency (see Roman dictator and justitium ).
DistractorFacts.title: Dictator - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: A person could be proclaimed as emperor by their troops or by "the mob" in the street, but in theory needed to be confirmed by the Senate. The coercion that frequently resulted was implied in this formulation.
DistractorFacts.title: List of Roman emperors - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Before the Marian reforms of 107 BC the structure of the legions was as follows: Contubernium – The smallest organized unit of soldiers in the Roman Army. It was composed of eight legionaries led by a decanus. When on the march a Legion would often march contubernium -abreast (8-abreast).
DistractorFacts.title: List of Roman army unit types - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: For the Latin term, see Roman legion. Legio was a Roman military camp south of Tel Megiddo in the Roman province of Galilee . Following the Bar Kokhba Revolt (132-136CE), Legio VI Ferrata was stationed at Legio near Caparcotna.
DistractorFacts.title: Legio - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Sagittarii (Latin, plural form of sagittarius) is the Latin term for archers. The term sagittariorum in the title of an infantry or cavalry unit indicated a specialized archer regiment. Regular auxiliary units of foot and horse archers appeared in the Roman army during the early empire.
DistractorFacts.title: Sagittarii - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The terms Western Roman Empire and Eastern Roman Empire were coined in modern times to describe political entities that were de facto independent; contemporary Romans did not consider the Empire to have been split into two separate empires but viewed it as a single polity governed by two separate imperial courts as an administrative expediency.
DistractorFacts.title: Western Roman Empire - Wikipedia

Question: What alphabet was Roman Gaul inscribed to in central France that was the original language of the Romans?
Answer: Latin.

SupportingFacts.fact: Latin was the original language of the Romans and remained the language of imperial administration, legislation, and the military throughout the classical period. In the West, it became the lingua franca and came to be used for even local administration of the cities including the law courts.
SupportingFacts.title: Languages of the Roman Empire - Wikipedia

SupportingFacts.fact: Later inscriptions dating to Roman Gaul are mostly in the Latin alphabet and have been found principally in central France. Latin was quickly adopted by the Gaulish aristocracy after the Roman conquest to maintain their elite power and influence, trilingualism in southern Gaul being noted as early as the 1st century BC.
SupportingFacts.title: Gaulish language - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: What follows is a list of inherited French words, past and present, along with words in neighboring or related languages, all borrowed from the Gaulish language (or more precisely from a substrate of Gaulish). W efwr 'cow parsnip', dial. (N) ewr, Br evor 'alder buckthorn', Sc iubhar 'yew', Ir iúr, OIr ibar
DistractorFacts.title: List of French words of Gaulish origin - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The word "Gaulish" ( gallicum) as a language term is first explicitly used in the Appendix Vergiliana in a poem referring to Gaulish letters of the alphabet.
DistractorFacts.title: Gaulish language - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: from Old French cresme, from the Latin word of Gaulish origin crāmum. from Old French changier, "to change, alter", from the late Latin word cambiare derived from an older Latin word cambire, "to barter, exchange", a word of Gaulish origin, from PIE root *kemb- "to bend, crook".
DistractorFacts.title: List of English words of Gaulish origin - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: A list of English Language words derived from the Celtic Gaulish language, entering English via Old Frankish or Vulgar Latin and Old French from Old French embassadeur, from Latin ambactus, from Gaulish *ambactos, "servant", "henchman", "one who goes about". from Old French bec, from Latin beccus, from Gaulish beccos.
DistractorFacts.title: List of English words of Gaulish origin - Wikipedia

Question: What anti convulsant is contained in Valeriana officinalis, Caprifoliaceae?
Answer: Valerian contains isovaltrate, an anti convulsant.

SupportingFacts.fact: With its base in Reno, Nevada, the RSIC consists of 1,134 members from three Great Basin tribes: the Paiute, the Shoshone and the Washoe. The reservation lands have been limited, consisting of the original 28-acre Colony located in central-west Reno ( / ﻿ 39.69194°N 119.74556°W ﻿ / 39.69194; -119.74556
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: Valeric acid which is responsible for the typical odor of mostly older valerian roots, does not have any sedative properties. Valproic acid, a widely prescribed anticonvulsant is a derivative of valeric acid. Valerian also contains isovaltrate, which has been shown to be an inverse agonist for adenosine A 1 receptor sites.
SupportingFacts.title: Valerian (herb) - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Acetic acid is produced and excreted by acetic acid bacteria, notably the genus Acetobacter and Clostridium acetobutylicum. These bacteria are found universally in foodstuffs, water, and soil, and acetic acid is produced naturally as fruits and other foods spoil.
DistractorFacts.title: Acetic acid - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Ceric ammonium nitrate (CAN) is the inorganic compound with the formula ( NH 4) 2 Ce (NO 3) 6. This orange-red, water-soluble cerium salt is a specialised oxidizing agent in organic synthesis and a standard oxidant in quantitative analysis . 3 in hot concentrated HNO 3 .
DistractorFacts.title: Ceric ammonium nitrate - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Its IUPAC name is 4,4-bis (4-hydroxyphenyl)pentanoic acid, and it can be prepared by the condensation reaction of phenol with levulinic acid in the presence of hydrochloric acid. The equation for this synthesis is:
DistractorFacts.title: Diphenolic acid - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Pantoic acid is an alpha hydroxy acid which is a component of some biologically active compounds. The amide of pantoic acid with β-alanine is pantothenic acid (vitamin B 5) and the amide with GABA is the pharmaceutical drug hopantenic acid. It is also a central component of coenzyme A . This article about an organic compound is a stub.
DistractorFacts.title: Pantoic acid - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Pentenoic acid is any of five mono-carboxylic acids whose molecule has an unbranched chain of five carbons conected by three single bonds and one double bond. That is, any compound with one of the formulas HO (O=)C–CH=CH– CH 2 ( 4-pentenoic ).
DistractorFacts.title: Pentenoic acid - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Usually found as an aqueous solution, this colorless compound is a stronger acid than sulfuric acid and nitric acid. It is a powerful oxidizer when hot, but aqueous solutions up to approximately 70% by weight at room temperature are generally safe, only showing strong acid features and no oxidizing properties.
DistractorFacts.title: Perchloric acid - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Valproic acid (VPA) is an organic weak acid. The conjugate base is valproate. The sodium salt of the acid is sodium valproate and a coordination complex of the two is known as valproate semisodium. It is used primarily to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder. It is also used to prevent migraine headaches.
DistractorFacts.title: Valproate - Wikipedia

Question: What are the Males of animals that are canids that either live in small family groups or are solitary called?
Answer: Male foxes are known as dogs, tods or reynards?

SupportingFacts.fact: The Human Torch (Johnny Storm) is a fictional superhero appearing in American comic books published by Marvel Comics. The character is a founding member of the Fantastic Four.
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: Unlike many canids, foxes are not always pack animals. Typically, they live in small family groups, but some (such as Arctic foxes) are known to be solitary. Foxes are omnivores. Their diet is made up primarily of invertebrates such as insects and small vertebrates such as reptiles and birds.
SupportingFacts.title: Fox - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Caniforms have single-chambered or partially divided auditory bullae, composed of a single bone, while in feliforms, the auditory bullae are double-chambered, composed of two bones joined by a septum. In the Canoidea, the bulbourethral glands and vesicula seminalis are always absent.
DistractorFacts.title: Caniformia - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Cetaceans includes whales, dolphins and porpoises. They are the mammals most fully adapted to aquatic life with a spindle-shaped nearly hairless body, protected by a thick layer of blubber, and forelimbs and tail modified to provide propulsion underwater.
DistractorFacts.title: List of mammals of Canada - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In CANopen the 11-bit id of a CAN-frame is known as communication object identifier, or COB-ID. In case of a transmission collision, the bus arbitration used in the CAN bus allows the frame with the smallest id to be transmitted first and without a delay. Using a low code number for time critical functions ensures the lowest possible delay.
DistractorFacts.title: CANopen - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Extinct species have also been placed into all of the extant subfamilies besides Helictidinae, in both extant and extinct genera; around 200 extinct Mustelidae species have been found, as well as fossil genera not given a species name, though due to ongoing research and discoveries the exact number and categorization is not fixed.
DistractorFacts.title: List of mustelids - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In English, it is a term sometimes used to denote a serious zoological approach to the study of dogs as well as by writers on canine subjects, dog breeders, trainers and enthusiasts who study the dog informally.
DistractorFacts.title: Cynology - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Animals that belong to the family Canidae are called canids. The family Canidae is divided into two tribes: Vulpini ("true foxes"), and Canini ("true dogs"). Canids of the tribe Vulpini (foxes) are called "vulpines".
DistractorFacts.title: Canidae - Simple English Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

DistractorFacts.fact: A group of foxes is referred to as a skulk, leash, or earth. Within the Canidae, the results of DNA analysis shows several phylogenetic divisions: The fox-like canids, which include the kit fox ( Vulpes velox ), red fox ( Vulpes vulpes ), Cape fox ( Vulpes chama ), Arctic fox ( Vulpes lagopus ), and fennec fox ( Vulpes zerda ).
DistractorFacts.title: Fox - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Canina is a taxonomic rank which represents the wolf-like sub- tribe of the tribe Canini, and is sister to the sub-tribe Cerdocyonina. Fossils of this group date to 5 million years ago, however they are likely to have been in existence 9 million years ago. Its members as a group are colloquially known as the wolf-like canids.
DistractorFacts.title: Canina (subtribe) - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Cynology / sɪˈnɒlədʒi / (rarely kynology, / kɪˈnɒlədʒi /) is the study of matters related to canines or domestic dogs. In English, it is a term sometimes used to denote a serious zoological approach to the study of dogs as well as by writers on canine subjects, dog breeders, trainers and enthusiasts who study the dog informally.
DistractorFacts.title: Cynology - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The caniforms are divided into eight families: Canidae, Mephitidae, Mustelidae, Odobenidae, Otariidae, Phocidae, Procyonidae, and Ursidae, and include the dogs, bears, raccoons, weasels, and pinnipeds.
DistractorFacts.title: List of carnivorans - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The South American gray fox, Lycalopex griseus, is the most common species, and is known for its large ears and a highly marketable, russet-fringed pelt . The second-oldest known fossils belonging to the genus were discovered in Chile, and date from 2.0 to 2.5 million years ago, in the mid- to late Pliocene.
DistractorFacts.title: South American fox - Wikipedia

Question: What area of study does Archaeology that is also seen in Acculturation?
Answer: They can both deal with the understanding of culture.

SupportingFacts.fact: Acculturation is a process of social, psychological, and cultural change that stems from the balancing of two cultures while adapting to the prevailing culture of the society. Acculturation is a process in which an individual adopts, acquires and adjusts to a new cultural environment.
SupportingFacts.title: Acculturation - Wikipedia

SupportingFacts.fact: Prehistory includes over 99% of the human past, from the Paleolithic until the advent of literacy in societies across the world. Archaeology has various goals, which range from understanding culture history to reconstructing past lifeways to documenting and explaining changes in human societies through time.
SupportingFacts.title: Archaeology - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Archaeology or archeology is the study of human activity through the recovery and analysis of material culture. Archaeology is often considered a branch of socio-cultural anthropology, but archaeologists also draw from biological, geological, and environmental systems through their study of the past.
DistractorFacts.title: Archaeology - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Binford withdrew from the theoretical debates that followed the rapid adoption of New Archaeology (by then also called processual archaeology) in the 1960s and 70s, instead focusing on his work on the Mousterian, a Middle Palaeolithic lithic industry found in Europe, North Africa and the Near East.
DistractorFacts.title: Lewis Binford - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Culture-historical thought would be introduced to British archaeology by the Australian archaeologist V. Gordon Childe in the late 1920s. In the United Kingdom and United States, culture-history came to be supplanted as the dominant theoretical paradigm in archaeology during the 1960s, with the rise of processual archaeology.
DistractorFacts.title: Culture-historical archaeology - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Flavio Biondo, an Italian Renaissance humanist historian, created a systematic guide to the ruins and topography of ancient Rome in the early 15th century, for which he has been called an early founder of archaeology.
DistractorFacts.title: History of archaeology - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In the 1980s, a new movement arose led by the British archaeologists Michael Shanks, Christopher Tilley, Daniel Miller and Ian Hodder.
DistractorFacts.title: Archaeological theory - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Likewise it is very often said, as the historian Arthur Marwick has, that ‘the 1960s’ began in the late 1950s and ended in the early 1970s. His reason for saying this is that the cultural and economic conditions that define the meaning of the period covers more than the accidental fact of a 10-year block beginning with the number 6.
DistractorFacts.title: Periodization - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: There was such a dearth of work in this area that it led Willey and Phillips to state in 1958, "So little work has been done in American archaeology on the explanatory level that it is difficult to find a name for it". Different researchers had different approaches to this problem.
DistractorFacts.title: Processual archaeology - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Wikimedia Commons has media related to Archaeological discoveries in the 1960s. This category is for archaeological discoveries in the decade 1960s, i.e. in the years 1960 to 1969 . This category has the following 10 subcategories, out of 10 total.
DistractorFacts.title: Category:1960s archaeological discoveries - Wikipedia

Question: What continent can the Melaleuca quinquenervia abd Melaleuca alternifolia species be found in?
Answer: Australia.

SupportingFacts.fact: In Australia, Melaleuca quinquenervia occurs along the east coast, from Cape York in Queensland to Botany Bay in New South Wales. It grows in seasonally inundated plains and swamps, along estuary margins and is often the dominant species.
SupportingFacts.title: Melaleuca quinquenervia - Wikipedia

SupportingFacts.fact: Melaleuca alternifolia, commonly known as tea tree, is a species of tree or tall shrub in the myrtle family, Myrtaceae. Endemic to Australia, it occurs in southeast Queensland and the north coast and adjacent ranges of New South Wales where it grows along streams and on swampy flats, and is often the dominant species where it occurs.
SupportingFacts.title: Melaleuca alternifolia - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: King was a tin miner by profession and followed his father, Charlie, to Melaleuca in 1936, where he built a house, which was accommodation for himself and workers as well as the airstrip which opened up tourism for the South West Wilderness.
DistractorFacts.title: Deny King - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Melaleuca ( / ˌmɛləˈljuːkə /) is a genus of nearly 300 species of plants in the myrtle family, Myrtaceae, commonly known as paperbarks, honey-myrtles or tea-trees (although the last name is also applied to species of Leptospermum ). They range in size from small shrubs that rarely grow to more than 16 m (52 ft) high, to trees up to 35 m (115 ft).
DistractorFacts.title: Melaleuca - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Melaleuca alternifolia is endemic to Australia and is found from the Grafton district in New South Wales as far inland as Stroud and in coastal districts north to Maryborough in Queensland. It grows along streams and in swampy places.
DistractorFacts.title: Melaleuca alternifolia - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: One ( M. howeana) is endemic to Lord Howe Island and seven are endemic to Grande Terre, the main island of New Caledonia. A few tropical species also occur in Papua New Guinea, and the distribution of one subspecies, Melaleuca cajuputi subsp. cumingiana extends as far north as Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam.
DistractorFacts.title: Melaleuca - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: This is a list of current registered airports in the Australian state of Tasmania . The list is sorted by the name of the community served, click the sort buttons in the table header to switch listing order. Airports named in bold are Designated International Airports, even if they have limited or no scheduled international services.
DistractorFacts.title: List of airports in Tasmania - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Two hiking trails meet at Melaleuca: the Port Davey Track and the South Coast Track. From the 1930s until the area gained World Heritage status, Melaleuca had been the location leased for mining ventures.
DistractorFacts.title: Melaleuca, Tasmania - Wikipedia

Question: What continent with the largest number of megafauna species does the Democratic Republic of the Congo belong to?
Answer: Africa.

SupportingFacts.fact: Africa is home to much biodiversity; it is the continent with the largest number of megafauna species, as it was least affected by the extinction of the Pleistocene megafauna. However, Africa also is heavily affected by a wide range of environmental issues, including desertification, deforestation, water scarcity, and other issues.
SupportingFacts.title: Africa - Wikipedia

SupportingFacts.fact: To the west lies Gabon; Cameroon to its northwest and the Central African Republic to its northeast; the Democratic Republic of the Congo to the southeast and the Angolan exclave of Cabinda to its south; and the Atlantic Ocean to its southwest. The official language is French .
SupportingFacts.title: Republic of the Congo - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Rutshuru Territory is a territory in the North Kivu province of the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), with headquarters is the town of Rutshuru . The territory is mountainous, including a large portion of the Virunga National Park, famous for its mountain gorillas.
DistractorFacts.title: Rutshuru Territory - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The Department of the Northwest sent expeditions into Dakota Territory in 1863, 1864 and 1865. It also established forts in Dakota Territory to protect the frontier settlements of the Territory, Iowa and Minnesota and the traffic along the Missouri River .
DistractorFacts.title: Dakota Territory - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The U.S. has five permanently inhabited territories: Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands in the Caribbean Sea, Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands in the North Pacific Ocean, and American Samoa in the South Pacific Ocean. American Samoa is in the Southern Hemisphere, while the other four are in the Northern Hemisphere.
DistractorFacts.title: Territories of the United States - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: African nations cooperate through the establishment of the African Union, which is headquartered in Addis Ababa . Africa straddles the Equator and encompasses numerous climate areas; it is the only continent to stretch from the northern temperate to southern temperate zones.
DistractorFacts.title: Africa - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Rutshuru Territory is a territory in the North Kivu province of the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), with headquarters is the town of Rutshuru . The territory is mountainous, including a large portion of the Virunga National Park, famous for its mountain gorillas. The people of the territory are extremely poor.
DistractorFacts.title: Rutshuru Territory - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Tifariti is the factual temporary capital, but Tindouf located in Algeria is the place of some government and military facilities. ^ Only the Îles Éparses are considered part of the African continent. The remaining four districts lie outside the continental shelf in the Indian Ocean or Antarctica.
DistractorFacts.title: List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Africa - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: 1200s - Rise of Kongo empire, centred in modern northern Angola and including extreme western Congo and territories round lakes Kisale and Upemba in central Katanga (now Shaba). 1482 - Portuguese navigator Diogo Cao becomes the first European to visit the Congo; Portuguese set up ties with the king of Kongo.
DistractorFacts.title: Democratic Republic of Congo profile - Timeline - BBC News

DistractorFacts.fact: As it straddles the Equator, it has territories in both the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. It is located to the east of the Prime Meridian in the Eastern Hemisphere. Nine countries border the DRC.
DistractorFacts.title: Democratic Republic Of The Congo Maps & Facts - World Atlas

DistractorFacts.fact: DR Congo provinces, territories, and a few cities. The Third Republic of the Democratic Republic of the Congo is a unitary state with a five-level hierarchy of types of administrative division. There are nine different types of country subdivision in a new hierarchy with no new types but with two from the previous one abolished.
DistractorFacts.title: Subdivisions of the Democratic Republic of the Congo - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Each of the five major territories has its own local court system: #High Court of American Samoa Supreme Court of Guam Supreme Court of the Northern Mariana Islands Supreme Court of Puerto Rico Supreme Court of the Virgin Islands
DistractorFacts.title: Territories of the United States - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: From the coast to the countryside and the inland areas, each municipality making up the Conero Riviera, has its own special features, with something to offer and stories to tell. Looking up from the boot, Mount Conero stands out as the only green promontory in a landscape that goes from Trieste to Gargano.
DistractorFacts.title: Hotel Marche Ancona Riviera Adriatica Portonovo Numana Sirolo Mare Adriatico - Sito ufficiale Albergatori Riviera del Conero

DistractorFacts.fact: Modern #Mamprussi (16th century CE–?) Kwararafa Confederacy (1500-1840 CE) Kaabu Empire (1537–1867 CE) Kingdom of Cayor (1549–1879 CE) Kingdom of Jolof (1549-1875) Kingdom of Baol (1555–1874 CE) Kingdom of Dahomey (1600–1900 CE) Aro Confederacy (1690–1902 CE) Asante Union (1701–Present) Kong Empire (1710–1894 CE) Bamana Empire (1712–1861 CE) Sokoto Caliphate (1804–1904 CE) Wukari Federation (1840-1900 CE) Wassoulou Empire (1878–1898 CE)
DistractorFacts.title: List of kingdoms in pre-colonial Africa - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Provinces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (Congo Kinshasa) #Updates: Fabien Antoine gave me a reference that shows that the reorganization under the new constitution has been passed into law. Country overview: At the start of the 20th century, the État Indépendant du Congo (Congo Free State) was the personal domain of King Léopold II of Belgium. Other names of country: Origin of name: Primary subdivisions: Democratic Republic of Congo is divided into twenty-five provinces and one ville neutre (neutral city), Kinshasa. Further subdivisions: See the Administrative Zones of the Democratic Republic of Congo page. ... Territorial extent: Sud-Kivu includes Île Idjwi, an island in Lake Kivu. ... Origins of names: Bas-Congo: French for lower Congo. Region lies along the lower reaches of the Congo River. ... Change history: Initially it contained four districts. More were created over the years. Province Orientale (O, capital Stanleyville). Other names of subdivisions: Sources: [1] Nouvelles entités provinciales , by Joseph M. Kyalangilwa, a Congolese living in Switzerland. The document has a few typos.
DistractorFacts.title: Democratic Republic of Congo Provinces

DistractorFacts.fact: Puerto Rico is the largest and most populous of the U.S. territories, with over 3 million residents. People born in Puerto Rico are granted U.S. citizenship. U.S. Virgin Islands: Located in the Caribbean Sea, just east of Puerto Rico.
DistractorFacts.title: Map of U.S. Territories

DistractorFacts.fact: The DRC is making headway against the Ebola epidemic, which has been raging for almost two years in the Nord Kivu, South Kivu, and Ituri provinces, where 3,453 cases and over 2,200 deaths have been reported.
DistractorFacts.title: Democratic Republic of Congo Overview

DistractorFacts.fact: The Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) is located in central sub-Saharan Africa, bounded by (clockwise from the southwest) Angola, the South Atlantic Ocean, the Republic of Congo, the Central African Republic, South Sudan, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, Tanzania across Lake Tanganyika, and Zambia.
DistractorFacts.title: Best Country: Geography of the Democratic Republic of the Congo

DistractorFacts.fact: The Simbas took control of a significant amount of territory and proclaimed a communist "People's Republic of the Congo" in Stanleyville. Government forces gradually retook territory and, in November 1964, Belgium and the United States intervened militarily in Stanleyville to recover hostages from Simba captivity.
DistractorFacts.title: Congo Crisis - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The Teke people occupy a series of savanna plateaus spanning more than 100,000km² across the length of the Republic of Congo, in areas such as Cuvette-Ouest, Niari, Bouenza and Lékoumou. Neighbouring tribes in the region include the Mbosi and the Kongo.
DistractorFacts.title: An Introduction to the Teke People of the Republic of Congo

DistractorFacts.fact: The Territory of Fizi is located in the East of the Democratic Republic of Congo. To the north is bounded by the territory of Uvira, to the West by the territory of Kabambare and to the East by Lake Tanganyika which separates it from the United Republic of Tanzania and the Republic of Burundi.
DistractorFacts.title: Fizi Territory Democratic Republic of Congo

DistractorFacts.fact: This is the central-northern part of Marche between Jesi and Fano, a strip of land stretching from the Adriatic coast to the slopes of the Apennines. Here in Verdicchio country, the variety has ancient roots and a strong, almost visceral, bond with the territory.
DistractorFacts.title: TERRITORIES AND VINEYARDS Marche and Abruzzo - Umani Ronchi

DistractorFacts.fact: — (1) This Order may be cited as the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Sanctions) (Overseas Territories) Order 2015. (2) It comes into force on 8th July 2015. (3) It extends to the territories listed in Schedule 1.
DistractorFacts.title: www.legislation.gov.uk

Question: What family are are moles which can be found in China, India, Myanmar, Thailand and Vietnam and carry a distinct hantavirus that is new to science?
Answer: The family of this rodent (which is the Chinese Mole Shrew) is Talpidae.

SupportingFacts.fact: For example, the spinning rotor may be suspended in a fluid, instead of being mounted in gimbals. A control moment gyroscope (CMG) is an example of a fixed-output-gimbal device that is used on spacecraft to hold or maintain a desired attitude angle or pointing direction using the gyroscopic resistance force.
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: The Scalopinae, or New World moles, are one of three subfamilies of the family Talpidae, which consists of moles and mole-like animals; the other two subfamilies being the Old World talpids (the Talpinae) and the Chinese shrew-like moles ( Uropsilinae ).
SupportingFacts.title: Scalopinae - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Scapanus is a genus of moles in the family Talpidae. They live in North America from west of the Rockies south to Baja California del Norte, and north to British Columbia, wherever conditions permit a mole population; that is to say, apart from the most sandy, rocky, or developed places.
DistractorFacts.title: Scapanus - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Scapanus latimanus is a fossorial mammal, living below ground for the most of its life. Only one animal occupies a burrow at a time and if a burrow has been vacated, it is often reoccupied within 2 days. Tunnels are typically dug far below surface level and the excess earth is removed via shafts that run laterally and vertically up to the surface.
DistractorFacts.title: Broad-footed mole - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The broad-footed mole ( Scapanus latimanus) is a species of mammal in the family Talpidae. It is found in Baja California in Mexico and in California, Nevada and Oregon in the United States at elevations up to 3000 m above sea level.
DistractorFacts.title: Broad-footed mole - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The coast mole or Pacific mole ( Scapanus orarius) is a medium-sized North American mole found in forested and open areas with moist soils along the Pacific coast from southwestern British Columbia to northwestern California . Two subspecies are recognized: the nominate, S. o. orarius, and Scheffer's coast mole, S. o. schefferi.
DistractorFacts.title: Coast mole - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The family Talpidae ( / ˈtælpɪdiː /) includes the moles, shrew moles, desmans, and other intermediate forms of small insectivorous mammals of the order Eulipotyphla.
DistractorFacts.title: Talpidae - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: They live in North America from west of the Rockies south to Baja California del Norte, and north to British Columbia, wherever conditions permit a mole population; that is to say, apart from the most sandy, rocky, or developed places. As they are one genus, they are very closely related, but as species, they rarely if ever interbreed successfully.
DistractorFacts.title: Scapanus - Wikipedia

Question: What family of probability distributions includes the normal distribution and a limiting uniform distribution is on the range -1 to +1?
Answer: The Gaussian q-distribution.

SupportingFacts.fact: The name Aragón is related to the birth area of the former kingdom, which corresponds to the modern autonomous community of Aragón in Spain. The river, used for irrigation and hydroelectric power, is about 129 kilometres (80 mi) long; its chief tributary is the Arga River.
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: In mathematical physicsand probabilityand statistics, the Gaussian q-distributionis a family of probability distributionsthat includes, as limiting cases, the uniform distributionand the normal (Gaussian) distribution. It was introduced by Diaz and Teruel,[clarification needed]is a q-analogueof the Gaussian or normal distribution.
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

DistractorFacts.fact: In analytical mechanics, the term generalized coordinates refers to the parameters that describe the configuration of the system relative to some reference configuration. These parameters must uniquely define the configuration of the system relative to the reference configuration. This is done assuming that this can be done with a single chart.
DistractorFacts.title: Generalized coordinates - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In probability theory and statistics, the multivariate normal distribution, multivariate Gaussian distribution, or joint normal distribution is a generalization of the one-dimensional ( univariate) normal distribution to higher dimensions.
DistractorFacts.title: Multivariate normal distribution - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Known also as the exponential power distribution, or the generalized error distribution, this is a parametric family of symmetric distributions. It includes all normal and Laplace distributions, and as limiting cases it includes all continuous uniform distributions on bounded intervals of the real line.
DistractorFacts.title: Generalized normal distribution - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The generalized normal distribution or generalized Gaussian distribution (GGD) is either of two families of parametric continuous probability distributions on the real line. Both families add a shape parameter to the normal distribution.
DistractorFacts.title: Generalized normal distribution - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The generalized velocities are the time derivatives of the generalized coordinates of the system. An example of a generalized coordinate is the angle that locates a point moving on a circle.
DistractorFacts.title: Generalized coordinates - Wikipedia

Question: What happened to the hump of the offspring when the hybrids known as cattalo were grown?
Answer: Beefalo or Cattalo have reduced hump size, compared to Buffalo.

SupportingFacts.fact: Autoroute 15, a sunken highway also known as the Décarie Expressway, soon filled with water, trapping motorists. Some 350,000 houses lost electricity, and tens of thousands had flooded basements. Two people died, one in a submerged car and another who was electrocuted.
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: The term "cattalo" is defined by United States law as a cross of bison and cattle which have a bison appearance. In Canada, however, the term is used for hybrids of all degrees and appearance. In some American states, cattalo are regulated as "exotic animals", along with pure bison and deer.
SupportingFacts.title: Beefalo - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: A dzo ( Tibetan མཛོ་ mdzo) (also spelled zo, zho and dzho) is a hybrid between the yak and domestic cattle. The word dzo technically refers to a male hybrid, while a female is known as a dzomo or zhom.
DistractorFacts.title: Dzo - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Bulls are much more muscular than cows, with thicker bones, larger feet, a very muscular neck, and a large, bony head with protective ridges over the eyes. These features assist bulls in fighting for domination over a herd, giving the winner superior access to cows for reproduction.
DistractorFacts.title: Bull - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In English, as in most other languages that have borrowed the word, "yak" is usually used for both sexes, with "bull" or "cow" referring to each sex separately. Yaks belong to the genus Bos and are therefore related to cattle ( Bos primigenius species).
DistractorFacts.title: Domestic yak - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In the early 20th century in Brazil, Zebu were crossbred with Charolais cattle, a European taurine breed. The resulting breed, 63% Charolais and 37% zebu, is called the Canchim. It has a better meat quality than the zebu and better heat resistance than European cattle.
DistractorFacts.title: Zebu - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: It was found early on that crossing a male bison with a domestic cow would produce few offspring, but that crossing a domestic bull with a bison cow apparently solved the problem. The female offspring proved fertile, but rarely so for the males.
DistractorFacts.title: Beefalo - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: It was produced by hybridisation experiments in the 1920s, when crosses were made between yak bulls and both pure bison cows and bison-cattle hybrid cows. As with many other inter-specific crosses, only female hybrids were found to be fertile ( Haldane's rule ).
DistractorFacts.title: Yakalo - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The European bison, B. bonasus, or wisent, is found in Europe and the Caucasus, reintroduced after being extinct in the wild . While all bison species are classified in their own genus, they are sometimes bred with domestic cattle (genus Bos) and produce sometimes fertile offspring called beefalo or zubron .
DistractorFacts.title: Bison - Wikipedia

Question: What is responsible for the odor of the roots of Valeriana officinalis, Caprifoliaceae?
Answer: Valeriana officinalis, Caprifoliaceae or Valerian roots odor is caused by Valproic acid.

SupportingFacts.fact: With its base in Reno, Nevada, the RSIC consists of 1,134 members from three Great Basin tribes: the Paiute, the Shoshone and the Washoe. The reservation lands have been limited, consisting of the original 28-acre Colony located in central-west Reno ( / ﻿ 39.69194°N 119.74556°W ﻿ / 39.69194; -119.74556
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: Valeric acid which is responsible for the typical odor of mostly older valerian roots, does not have any sedative properties. Valproic acid, a widely prescribed anticonvulsant is a derivative of valeric acid. Valerian also contains isovaltrate, which has been shown to be an inverse agonist for adenosine A 1 receptor sites.
SupportingFacts.title: Valerian (herb) - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Acetic acid is produced and excreted by acetic acid bacteria, notably the genus Acetobacter and Clostridium acetobutylicum. These bacteria are found universally in foodstuffs, water, and soil, and acetic acid is produced naturally as fruits and other foods spoil.
DistractorFacts.title: Acetic acid - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Ceric ammonium nitrate (CAN) is the inorganic compound with the formula ( NH 4) 2 Ce (NO 3) 6. This orange-red, water-soluble cerium salt is a specialised oxidizing agent in organic synthesis and a standard oxidant in quantitative analysis . 3 in hot concentrated HNO 3 .
DistractorFacts.title: Ceric ammonium nitrate - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Its IUPAC name is 4,4-bis (4-hydroxyphenyl)pentanoic acid, and it can be prepared by the condensation reaction of phenol with levulinic acid in the presence of hydrochloric acid. The equation for this synthesis is:
DistractorFacts.title: Diphenolic acid - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Pantoic acid is an alpha hydroxy acid which is a component of some biologically active compounds. The amide of pantoic acid with β-alanine is pantothenic acid (vitamin B 5) and the amide with GABA is the pharmaceutical drug hopantenic acid. It is also a central component of coenzyme A . This article about an organic compound is a stub.
DistractorFacts.title: Pantoic acid - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Pentenoic acid is any of five mono-carboxylic acids whose molecule has an unbranched chain of five carbons conected by three single bonds and one double bond. That is, any compound with one of the formulas HO (O=)C–CH=CH– CH 2 ( 4-pentenoic ).
DistractorFacts.title: Pentenoic acid - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Usually found as an aqueous solution, this colorless compound is a stronger acid than sulfuric acid and nitric acid. It is a powerful oxidizer when hot, but aqueous solutions up to approximately 70% by weight at room temperature are generally safe, only showing strong acid features and no oxidizing properties.
DistractorFacts.title: Perchloric acid - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Valproic acid (VPA) is an organic weak acid. The conjugate base is valproate. The sodium salt of the acid is sodium valproate and a coordination complex of the two is known as valproate semisodium. It is used primarily to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder. It is also used to prevent migraine headaches.
DistractorFacts.title: Valproate - Wikipedia

Question: What is the assumption of the root of the word that is  a folkloric genre and dance from Colombia?
Answer: Cumbia is derived from the Bantu root kumbe.

SupportingFacts.fact: Phosgene is a valued industrial building block, especially for the production of precursors of polyurethanes and polycarbonate plastics. It is very poisonous and was used as a chemical weapon during World War I, when it was responsible for 85,000 deaths .
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: Most folklorists and musicologists, such as Narciso Garay, Delia Zapata Olivella, and Guillermo Abadia Morales, assume that cumbia is derived from the Bantu root kumbe "to dance", or any other of the many Bantu words with "comb" or "kumb". Cf. samba, macumba .
SupportingFacts.title: Cumbia (Colombia) - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Colombian music is promoted mainly by the support of the largest record labels, independent companies and the Government of Colombia, through the Ministry of Culture . Colombia is known as "The land of a thousand rhythms" but actually holds over 1,025 folk rhythms. Some of the best known genres are cumbia and vallenato.
DistractorFacts.title: Music of Colombia - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Culturally, Cuba is considered part of Latin America. It is a multiethnic country whose people, culture and customs derive from diverse origins, including the Taíno Ciboney peoples, the long period of Spanish colonialism, the introduction of African slaves and a close relationship with the Soviet Union in the Cold War .
DistractorFacts.title: Cuba - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In music of Afro-Cuban origin, tumbao is the basic rhythm played on the bass. In North America, the basic conga drum pattern used in popular music is also called tumbao. In the contemporary form of Cuban popular dance music known as timba, piano guajeos are known as tumbaos.
DistractorFacts.title: Tumbao - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: It originated in the northern regions of Cuba, mainly in urban Havana and Matanzas, during the late 19th century. It is based on African music and dance traditions, namely Abakuá and yuka, as well as the Spanish-based coros de clave.
DistractorFacts.title: Cuban rumba - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Panamanian cumbia, a Panamanian musical genre and folk dance, developed by blacks enslaved during the colonial period and later syncretized with Amerindian and European cultural elements This disambiguation page lists articles associated with the title Cumbia.
DistractorFacts.title: Cumbia (disambiguation) - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Rumba is a secular genre of Cuban music involving dance, percussion, and song. It originated in the northern regions of Cuba, mainly in urban Havana and Matanzas, during the late 19th century. It is based on African music and dance traditions, namely Abakuá and yuka, as well as the Spanish-based coros de clave.
DistractorFacts.title: Cuban rumba - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Salvadoran cumbia is a staple in Salvadoran music. Groups such as Orquesta San Vicente who sing (Soy Salvadoreño), the Bravo group who sing (Sabrosa Cumbia) and the Hermanos Flores group who sing (Mi Pais) are three well known cumbia music groups in El Salvador.
DistractorFacts.title: Music of El Salvador - Wikipedia

Question: What is the brightest star in the night sky that was originally composed of two bright bluish stars?
Answer: Sirius.

SupportingFacts.fact: A street prostitute in Zona Norte, Tijuana. Prostitution in Mexico is legal under Federal Law. Each of the 31 states enacts its own prostitution laws and policies. Thirteen of the states of Mexico allow and regulate prostitution. Prostitution involving minors under 18 is illegal.
SupportingFacts.title: en.m.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: It was originally composed of two bright bluish stars. The more massive of these, Sirius B, consumed its resources and became a red giant before shedding its outer layers and collapsing into its current state as a white dwarf around 120 million years ago.
SupportingFacts.title: Sirius - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The name blue giant is sometimes misapplied to other high-mass luminous stars, such as main-sequence stars, simply because they are large and hot. Blue giant Bellatrix compared to Algol B, the Sun, a red dwarf, and some planets. Blue giant is not a strictly defined term and it is applied to a wide variety of different types of stars.
DistractorFacts.title: Blue giant - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Spectral types are named with a letter. The seven main types are M, K, G, F, A, B and O. M stars are the coldest stars and O stars are the hottest. The full system contains other types that are hard to find: W, R, N, and S .
DistractorFacts.title: Stellar classification - Simple English Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The lines of ionized silicon are used to determine the sub-class of the B-type stars, while magnesium lines are used to distinguish between the temperature classes. Type-B stars don't have a corona and lack a convection zone in their outer atmosphere.
DistractorFacts.title: B-type main-sequence star - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Type B killer whales, also known as Park Ice Orcas, are gray, black, and white colored with a dorsal cape and a very large eye patch. They are located in loose-packed ice waters and prey upon pinnipeds. They may seem to appear brown or yellowish due to the presence of diatoms in the water and have a cape of pale color.
DistractorFacts.title: Dwarf killer whale - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: What they have in common is: a moderate increase in size and luminosity compared to main-sequence stars of the same mass or temperature, and are hot enough to be called blue, meaning spectral class O, B, and sometimes early A.
DistractorFacts.title: Blue giant - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: A slash ( /) means that a star is either one class or the other. A dash ( -) means that the star is in between the two classes. For example, a star classified as A3-4III/IV would be in between spectral types A3 and A4, while being either a giant star or a subgiant.
DistractorFacts.title: Stellar classification - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Because a main-sequence star is referred to as a dwarf star, this class of star may also be termed a yellow-white dwarf (not to be confused with white dwarfs, a possible final stage of stellar evolution ). Famous examples include Procyon A, Gamma Virginis A and B, and KIC 8462852 .
DistractorFacts.title: F-type main-sequence star - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Notable gemstones which contain beryllium include beryl ( aquamarine, emerald) and chrysoberyl. As a free element it is a steel-gray, strong, lightweight and brittle alkaline earth metal .
DistractorFacts.title: Beryllium - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: O class and early B class stars with initial masses around 10–300 M☉ evolve away from the main sequence in just a few million years as their hydrogen is consumed and heavy elements start to appear near the surface of the star. These stars usually become blue supergiants, although it is possible that some of them evolve directly to Wolf–Rayet stars.
DistractorFacts.title: Blue supergiant star - Wikipedia

Question: What is the colloquial term for Area 2 of the Shinjuku district that shares the same phonetics as the wire that is used for its ability to withstand the high temperatures in a kiln?
Answer: They are both nichome.

SupportingFacts.fact: Nichrome wire is used for its ability to withstand the high temperatures that occur when clay work is fired in a kiln . Nichrome wire can be used as an alternative to platinum wire for flame testing by colouring the non-luminous part of a flame to detect cations such as sodium, potassium, copper, calcium, etc.
SupportingFacts.title: Nichrome - Wikipedia

SupportingFacts.fact: Shinjuku Ni-chōme (新宿二丁目), referred to colloquially as Ni-chōme or simply Nichō, is Area 2 in the Shinjuku District of the Shinjuku Special Ward of Tokyo, Japan.
SupportingFacts.title: Shinjuku Ni-chōme - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: A nickel is a five- cent coin struck by the United States Mint. Composed of 75% copper and 25% nickel, the piece has been issued since 1866. Its diameter is .835 inches (21.21 mm) and its thickness is .077 inches (1.95 mm).
DistractorFacts.title: Nickel (United States coin) - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Chromium is the main additive in stainless steel, to which it adds anti-corrosive properties. Chromium is also highly valued as a metal that is able to be highly polished while resisting tarnishing.
DistractorFacts.title: Chromium - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Electrical elements are conceptual abstractions representing idealized electrical components, such as resistors, capacitors, and inductors, used in the analysis of electrical networks. All electrical networks can be analyzed as multiple electrical elements interconnected by wires.
DistractorFacts.title: Electrical element - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: It was written by Dave Staugas, a programmer at Atari Corporation and co-author of the ST's operating system. NEOchrome supports hardware-supported color cycling to give the impression of animation. A color cycling waterfall, created with NEOchrome, was one of the iconic images of the early Atari ST.
DistractorFacts.title: NEOchrome - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Metalloproteins containing nickel are found in biological systems. Nickel forms simple binary compounds with non metals including halogens, chalcogenides, and pnictides. Nickel ions can act as a cation in salts with many acids, including common oxoacids.
DistractorFacts.title: Nickel compounds - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Meteorites are sometimes made of naturally occurring alloys of iron and nickel, but are not native to the Earth. One of the first alloys made by humans was bronze, which is a mixture of the metals tin and copper.
DistractorFacts.title: Alloy - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: NEOchrome is an early color bitmap graphics editor for the Atari ST. It was written by Dave Staugas, a programmer at Atari Corporation and co-author of the ST's operating system. NEOchrome supports hardware-supported color cycling to give the impression of animation.
DistractorFacts.title: NEOchrome - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Nichrome is an alloy. It is made of nickel and chromium. It has an 80/20% composition. It is used as a heating element. It gets hot when electricity goes through it. It is normally silver in colour and a wire. This short article about chemistry can be made longer.
DistractorFacts.title: Nichrome - Simple English Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Nickel titanium, also known as Nitinol, is a metal alloy of nickel and titanium, where the two elements are present in roughly equal atomic percentages. Different alloys are named according to the weight percentage of nickel, e.g. Nitinol 55 and Nitinol 60.
DistractorFacts.title: Nickel titanium - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Stainless steel is a group of iron -based alloys that contain a minimum of approximately 11% chromium, a composition that prevents the iron from rusting and also provides heat-resistant properties.
DistractorFacts.title: Stainless steel - Wikipedia

SupportingFacts.fact: Pukapuka, formerly Danger Island, is a coral atoll in the northern group of the Cook Islands in the Pacific Ocean. It is one of most remote islands of the Cook Islands, situated about 1,140 kilometres (708 miles) northwest of Rarotonga.

Question: What is the name of the Patron God of Babylon that has a physical representation as the Statue of Bêl?
Answer: Their name is Marduk.

SupportingFacts.fact: The Statue of Marduk, also known as the Statue of Bêl ( Bêl, meaning "lord", being a common designation for Marduk ), was the physical representation of the god Marduk, the patron deity of the ancient city of Babylon, traditionally housed in the city's main temple, the Esagila.
SupportingFacts.title: Statue of Marduk - Wikipedia

SupportingFacts.fact: The Patron God of Babylon was Marduk, and this god was recognized in Babylonian astrology as the planet Jupiter. Marduk was recognized as the most powerful god, but not the one and only god. The Babylonians were polytheistic, believing in many gods with different purposes, and they associated certain gods to certain planets.
SupportingFacts.title: Babylonian astrology - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In Babylonian religion, the ritual care and worship of the statues of deities were considered sacred; the gods lived simultaneously in their statues in temples and in the natural forces they embodied. An elaborate ceremony of washing the mouths of the statues appeared sometime in the Old Babylonian period.
DistractorFacts.title: Babylonian religion - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In the religion of ancient Babylon, Tiamat ( Akkadian: 𒀭𒋾𒊩𒆳 D TI.AMAT or 𒀭𒌓𒌈 D TAM.TUM, Greek: Θαλάττη Thaláttē) is a primordial goddess of the sea, mating with Abzû, the god of the groundwater, to produce younger gods. She is the symbol of the chaos of primordial creation.
DistractorFacts.title: Tiamat - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Similar to statues of deities in other cities in Mesopotamia, the Babylonians conflated this statue with their actual god, believing that Marduk himself resided in their city through the statue. As such, the statue held enormous religious significance.
DistractorFacts.title: Statue of Marduk - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: This statue was nicknamed the Asullḫi and was made of a type of wood called mēsu and covered with gold and silver. Similar to statues of deities in other cities in Mesopotamia, the Babylonians conflated this statue with their actual god, believing that Marduk himself resided in their city through the statue.
DistractorFacts.title: Statue of Marduk - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Babylonian religion is the religious practice of Babylonia. Babylonian mythology was greatly influenced by their Sumerian counterparts and was written on clay tablets inscribed with the cuneiform script derived from Sumerian cuneiform. The myths were usually either written in Sumerian or Akkadian.
DistractorFacts.title: Babylonian religion - Wikipedia

Question: What is the term that refers to the full travel of the piston along the cylinder in the structure's cylinder wall that is a thin sleeve surrounding the piston head?
Answer: A stroke.

SupportingFacts.fact: Perineal hernia is a hernia involving the perineum ( pelvic floor ). The hernia may contain fluid, fat, any part of the intestine, the rectum, or the bladder. It is known to occur in humans, dogs, and other mammals, and often appears as a sudden swelling to one side (sometimes both sides) of the anus .
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: The cylinder wall is a thin sleeve surrounding the piston head which creates a space for the combustion of fuel and the genesis of mechanical energy. DistractorFacts.fact: A jet engine is a type of reaction engine discharging a fast-moving jet that generates thrust by jet propulsion. While this broad definition can include rocket, water jet, and hybrid propulsion, the term jet engine typically refers to an airbreathing jet engine such as a turbojet, turbofan, ramjet, or pulse jet.
DistractorFacts.title: Jet engine - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: An engine or motor is a machine designed to convert one form of energy into mechanical energy. Heat engines, like the internal combustion engine, burn a fuel to create heat which is then used to do work.
DistractorFacts.title: Engine - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Engin Özdemir (born 1 October 1968) is a Turkish former professional footballer who played as a right midfielder and winger. He is best known for playing for Gençlerbirliği. He is also the father of Youtuber CaniSports.
DistractorFacts.title: Engin Özdemir - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Ethanol fuel mixtures have "E" numbers which describe the percentage of ethanol fuel in the mixture by volume, for example, E85 is 85% anhydrous ethanol and 15% gasoline. Low-ethanol blends, from E5 to E25, although internationally the most common use of the term refers to the E10 blend.
DistractorFacts.title: Common ethanol fuel mixtures - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In 1206, al-Jazari employed a crank - conrod system for two of his water-raising machines. A rudimentary steam turbine device was described by Taqi al-Din in 1551 and by Giovanni Branca in 1629. In the 13th century, the solid rocket motor was invented in China.

DistractorFacts.fact: Relevant discussion may be found on the talk page. Please help improve this article by introducing citations to additional sources. A spark-ignition engine ( SI engine) is an internal combustion engine, generally a petrol engine, where the combustion process of the air-fuel mixture is ignited by a spark from a spark plug.
DistractorFacts.title: Spark-ignition engine - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The first commercial steam-powered device was a water pump, developed in 1698 by Thomas Savery. It used condensing steam to create a vacuum which raised water from below and then used steam pressure to raise it higher. Small engines were effective though larger models were problematic.

DistractorFacts.fact: The first internet search engines predate the debut of the Web in December 1990: Who is user search dates back to 1982, and the Knowbot Information Service multi-network user search was first implemented in 1989. DistractorFacts.fact: The steam engine, the major driver in the Industrial Revolution, underscores the importance of engineering in modern history. This beam engine is on display in the Technical University of Madrid.

Question: What large and unusual trait was shared by Homer's ancestors and Emperor Keiko?
Answer: Keiko and some of Homer's ancestors were Giants.

SupportingFacts.fact: Homer has Giants among the ancestors of the Phaiakians, a race of men encountered by Odysseus, their ruler Alcinous being the son of Nausithous, who was the son of Poseidon and Periboea, the daughter of the Giant king Eurymedon.
SupportingFacts.title: Giants (Greek mythology) - Wikipedia

SupportingFacts.fact: Emperor Keikō - According to records, this 1st century AD emperor stood 10ft 2in tall. Emperor Chūai - Was said to be ten feet tall, with "a countenance of perfect beauty".
SupportingFacts.title: List of giants in mythology and folklore - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Giants' tomb (Italian: Tomba dei giganti, Sardinian: Tumba de zigantes / gigantis) is the name given by local people and archaeologists to a type of Sardinian megalithic gallery grave built during the Bronze Age by the Nuragic civilization.
DistractorFacts.title: Giants' grave - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In Greek and Roman Mythology, the Giants, also called Gigantes ( Greek: Γίγαντες, Gígantes, singular: Γίγας, Gígas ), were a race of great strength and aggression, though not necessarily of great size. They were known for the Gigantomachy ( Gigantomachia ), their battle with the Olympian gods.
DistractorFacts.title: Giants (Greek mythology) - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In Islam, giants known as jababirat or jabbirun ( Arabic: جبارون ‎ "tyrants" or "giants"; singular, Arabic: جبار ‎ Jabbar) such as Jalut (Goliath) are mentioned, as well as ‘Uj ibn Anaq. The Book of Enoch describes giants as the offspring of Watchers and women in 7:2. Hayk was known as the founder of the Armenian state.
DistractorFacts.title: Giant - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The vanquished Giants were said to be buried under volcanoes and to be the cause of volcanic eruptions and earthquakes. The name "Gigantes" is usually taken to imply "earth-born", and Hesiod 's Theogony makes this explicit by having the Giants be the offspring of Gaia (Earth).
DistractorFacts.title: Giants (Greek mythology) - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: They were known for the Gigantomachy ( Gigantomachia ), their battle with the Olympian gods. According to Hesiod, the Giants were the offspring of Gaia (Earth), born from the blood that fell when Uranus (Sky) was castrated by his Titan son Cronus.

Question: What lumbar plexus-originating nerve pierces through the transversus abdominis and divides between that muscle and the internal oblique muscle?
Answer: The iliohypogastric nerve.

SupportingFacts.fact: Centralia Big Hanaford power plant is a major coal-fired power plant supplemented with newer natural-gas-fired units. It is located east of Centralia, Washington, United States in Lewis County.

SupportingFacts.fact: Near the iliac crest the iliohypogastric nerve then pierces through the transversus abdominis and divides between that muscle and the internal oblique muscle into a lateral and an anterior cutaneous branch.

DistractorFacts.fact: Anterior cutaneous nerve entrapment syndrome ( ACNES) is a nerve entrapment condition that causes chronic pain of the abdominal wall.

DistractorFacts.fact: Here they communicate with the anterior division of lateral cutaneous nerve, the anterior division of medial cutaneous nerve and the infrapatellar branch of the saphenous, to form the patellar plexus .

DistractorFacts.fact: It occurs when nerve endings of the lower thoracic intercostal nerves (7–12) are 'entrapped' in abdominal muscles, causing a severe localized nerve (neuropathic) pain that is usually experienced at the front of the abdomen. ACNES syndrome is frequently overlooked and unrecognized, although the incidence is estimated to be 1:2000 patients.

DistractorFacts.fact: The anterior cutaneous branches of the femoral nerve consist of the following nerves: intermediate cutaneous nerve and medial cutaneous nerve .
DistractorFacts.title: Anterior cutaneous branches of the femoral nerve - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: When harvesting bone from the anterior iliac crest (AICBG), the lateral cutaneous branch of the Iliohypogastric nerve (L1) is most likely to be injured. Area supplied by the lateral cutaneous branch can be seen in blue near the hip.

DistractorFacts.fact: The iliohypogastric nerve originates from the superior branch of the anterior ramus of spinal nerve L1 after this nerve receives fibers from T12 via the subcostal nerve. The inferior branch is the ilioinguinal nerve .

Answer: The eardrum.

SupportingFacts.fact: Photovoltaics (PVs) are arrays of cells containing a solar photovoltaic material that converts solar radiation or energy from the sun into direct current electricity. Due to the growing demand for renewable energy sources, the manufacturing of solar cells and photovoltaic arrays has advanced considerably in recent years, and costs have dropped.
SupportingFacts.title: en.wikipedia.org

SupportingFacts.fact: In the anatomy of humans and various other tetrapods, the eardrum, also called the tympanic membrane or myringa, is a thin, cone-shaped membrane that separates the external ear from the middle ear. Its function is to transmit sound from the air to the ossicles inside the middle ear, and then to the oval window in the fluid-filled cochlea.
SupportingFacts.title: Eardrum - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: In human anatomy, the pars flaccida of tympanic membrane or Shrapnell's membrane (also known as Rivinus' ligament) is the small, triangular, flaccid portion of the tympanic membrane, or eardrum. It lies above the malleolar folds attached directly to the petrous bone at the notch of Rivinus.
DistractorFacts.title: Pars flaccida of tympanic membrane - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: It lies above the malleolar folds attached directly to the petrous bone at the notch of Rivinus. On the inner surface of the tympanic membrane, the chorda tympani crosses this area.

DistractorFacts.fact: The petrotympanic fissure opens just above and in front of the ring of bone into which the tympanic membrane is inserted; in this situation it is a mere slit about 2 mm. in length. It lodges the anterior process and anterior ligament of the malleus, and gives passage to the anterior tympanic branch of the internal maxillary artery.
DistractorFacts.title: Tympanic cavity - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The tympanic cavity is a small cavity surrounding the bones of the middle ear. Within it sit the ossicles, three small bones that transmit vibrations used in the detection of sound . On its lateral surface, it abuts the external auditory meatus [ ear canal ] from which it is separated by the tympanic membrane (eardrum).

DistractorFacts.fact: This ring of bone is incomplete at its upper part, forming a notch (notch of Rivinus), close to which are three small apertures: the "iter chordæ posterius", the petrotympanic fissure, and the "iter chordæ anterius".

Question: What name is misapplied to other high-mass luminous stars that are hot enough to be called blue?
Answer: Blue giant.

SupportingFacts.fact: The name blue giant is sometimes misapplied to other high-mass luminous stars, such as main-sequence stars, simply because they are large and hot. Blue giant Bellatrix compared to Algol B, the Sun, a red dwarf, and some planets. Blue giant is not a strictly defined term and it is applied to a wide variety of different types of stars.
SupportingFacts.title: Blue giant - Wikipedia

SupportingFacts.fact: What they have in common is: a moderate increase in size and luminosity compared to main-sequence stars of the same mass or temperature, and are hot enough to be called blue, meaning spectral class O, B, and sometimes early A.
SupportingFacts.title: Blue giant - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Spectral types are named with a letter. The seven main types are M, K, G, F, A, B and O. M stars are the coldest stars and O stars are the hottest. The full system contains other types that are hard to find: W, R, N, and S .
DistractorFacts.title: Stellar classification - Simple English Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

DistractorFacts.fact: The lines of ionized silicon are used to determine the sub-class of the B-type stars, while magnesium lines are used to distinguish between the temperature classes. Type-B stars don't have a corona and lack a convection zone in their outer atmosphere.
DistractorFacts.title: B-type main-sequence star - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Type B killer whales, also known as Park Ice Orcas, are gray, black, and white colored with a dorsal cape and a very large eye patch. They are located in loose-packed ice waters and prey upon pinnipeds. They may seem to appear brown or yellowish due to the presence of diatoms in the water and have a cape of pale color.
DistractorFacts.title: Dwarf killer whale - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: A slash ( /) means that a star is either one class or the other. A dash ( -) means that the star is in between the two classes. For example, a star classified as A3-4III/IV would be in between spectral types A3 and A4, while being either a giant star or a subgiant.
DistractorFacts.title: Stellar classification - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: It was originally composed of two bright bluish stars. The more massive of these, Sirius B, consumed its resources and became a red giant before shedding its outer layers and collapsing into its current state as a white dwarf around 120 million years ago.
DistractorFacts.title: Sirius - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Because a main-sequence star is referred to as a dwarf star, this class of star may also be termed a yellow-white dwarf (not to be confused with white dwarfs, a possible final stage of stellar evolution ). Famous examples include Procyon A, Gamma Virginis A and B, and KIC 8462852 .
DistractorFacts.title: F-type main-sequence star - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: Notable gemstones which contain beryllium include beryl ( aquamarine, emerald) and chrysoberyl. As a free element it is a steel-gray, strong, lightweight and brittle alkaline earth metal .
DistractorFacts.title: Beryllium - Wikipedia

DistractorFacts.fact: O class and early B class stars with initial masses around 10–300 M☉ evolve away from the main sequence in just a few million years as their hydrogen is consumed and heavy elements start to appear near the surface of the star. These stars usually become blue supergiants, although it is possible that some of them evolve directly to Wolf–Rayet stars.
